urn:contentItem:600V-W8S1-JDK3-90MW-00000-00Trump goes after political bias in executive order that targets Twitter and Facebook2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:44ZLexisNexisWORLDTrump goes after political bias in executive order that targets Twitter and Facebook

U.S. President Donald Trump is expected to order a review of a law that has long protected Twitter, Facebook and Alphabet's Google from being responsible for the material posted by their users, according to a draft executive order and a source familiar with the situation.

News of the order comes after Trump threatened to shut down websites he accused of stifling conservative voices following a dispute with Twitter after the company decided to tag Trump's tweets about unsubstantiated claims of fraud in mail-in voting with a warning prompting readers to fact-check the posts.

The order, a draft copy of which was seen by Reuters, could change before it is finalized. On Wednesday, officials said Trump will sign an executive order on social media companies on Thursday.

Twitter has now shown that everything we have been saying about them (and their other compatriots) is correct. Big action to follow!

- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 27, 2020( https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1265649545410744321?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw )

The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The executive order would require the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to propose and clarify regulations under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a federal law largely exempting online platforms from legal liability for the material their users post. Such changes could expose tech companies to more lawsuits.

The order asks the FCC to examine whether actions related to the editing of content by social media companies should potentially lead to the platform forfeiting its protections under section 230.

It requires the agency to look at whether a social media platform uses deceptive policies to moderate content and if its policies are inconsistent with its terms of service.

Big Tech is doing everything in their very considerable power to CENSOR in advance of the 2020 Election. If that happens, we no longer have our freedom. I will never let it happen! They tried hard in 2016, and lost. Now they are going absolutely CRAZY. Stay Tuned!!!

- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 28, 2020( https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1265819308699070464?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw )

The draft order also states that the White House Office of Digital Strategy will re-establish a tool to help citizens report cases of online censorship.

Called the White House Tech Bias Reporting Tool, it will collect complaints of online censorship and submit them to the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

It requires the FTC to then "consider taking action," look into whether complaints violate the law, develop a report describing such complaints and make the report publicly available.

The draft order also requires the Attorney General to establish a working group including state attorneys general that will examine the enforcement of state laws that prohibit online platforms from engaging in unfair and deceptive acts.

Amid feud with Twitter, Trump to sign executive order on social media Thursday, White House says( https://nationalpost.com/news/world/amid-feud-with-twitter-trump-to-sign-executive-order-on-social-media-thursday-white-house-says )

Twitter's fact-check label prompts Trump threat to shut down social media companies( https://nationalpost.com/news/world/twitter-fact-checks-trumps-rant-about-mail-in-ballot-fraud-while-facebook-lets-the-discussion-continue-unabated )

The working group will also monitor or create watch-lists of users based on their interactions with content or other users.

Federal spending on online advertising will also be reviewed by U.S. government agencies to ensure there are no speech restrictions by the relevant platform.

It requires the head of each agency to report its findings to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, within 30 days of the date of this order. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

urn:contentItem:5RGY-8NG1-DY0W-42T7-00000-00Trump Goes To Davos World Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have A2018-01-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:44ZLexisNexisTrump Goes To Davos World Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have ALanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Wednesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. It is Wednesday, January 24th. The top stories right now 8:00 A.M. on the East Coast. America First on the world stage. President Trump and his administration heads to Davos to tout the U.S. economy and lure big-name investors to America. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin making headline down the ground in Davos already. The dollar is down this morning after Secretary Mnuchin said a weaker dollar is good for the U.S. economy. He's not the only cabinet member making headlines. Earlier this morning, I spoke with Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen about the delegation to the World Economic Forum.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY: I think what this message is going to be is America First is not America alone. We need to partner, you know, as I said earlier, not one of us has the ability to do this alone. So we need to partner with the private secretary. We need to partner with our allies. We've seen those discussions with North Korea. We've seen that in Syria. We've seen that in Iran. We have to build coalitions to be able to attack these threats together and I think -- I think that's what you'll hear a lot about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The president's trip to Davos comes amid another case of trickle-down tax reform. Starbucks, the latest company passing on savings from the new tax law to its employees. The announcement coming on the heels of similar news from Disney, J.P. Morgan Chase, and Verizon and that was just yesterday. What the coffee giant is brewing up for its records coming up. New and more records from markets, the NASDAQ yesterday surged 52 points after Netflix stock jumped 10 percent. The S&P 500 also added all-time high this morning after another gain yesterday of 6 points quarter of a percent higher. The Dow pulled back yesterday but this morning we look at momentum on the upside we're expecting a pretty strong opening for the broader averages. Take a look at Futures with the Dow Industrials now at the highs of the morning. We're expecting a gain of 80 points right out of the gate a third of a percent higher, S&P 500 also higher by a quarter of a percent, and the NASDAQ adding on to yesterday's record performance.

In Europe, this morning different story. Take a look at the European indices lower across the board worst performer in the U.K. FT-100 down one half of one percent. In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher with the exception of Japan as you see the Nikkei averaging Japan down three- quarters of a percent overnight. Earnings, the story on Wall Street once again General Electric, Ford Motor, Comcast, all among the big names reporting their fourth quarter numbers. Comcast delivered a double beat earnings and revenue above estimates. General Electric missed estimates but look at the stock, it's up one and one and a half percent. Clearly, investors are seeing some value in G.E. shares after a 40 percent sell-off despite that miss on earnings.

And again, the United States in the back controlling a country with this industry. It's about literally freeing up our allies around the world. Letting them know that we're going to be there for them, there's no strings attached when you buy American LNG. So, that is -- that's world-changing. And truly, this president, that's his message here. Is that the United States is -- it's a new day. The fossil fuels that we're going to be relying them on for decades to come are going to be available. Now, is our technology going to be able to allow us to use it wiser? With better results for the environment? Absolutely. The CCCU, the carbon capture utilization, we're doing projects with Saudi Arabia.

I'll see my counterpart (INAUDIBLE) today on a panel, we'll talk about the projects that we're working on together. The UAE, Qatar, all of those countries as we come together to develop and supply the rest of the world with the power so that they can have manufacturing (INAUDIBLE) in Africa. Being able to, you know, literally turn the lights on when the sun goes down so that their children can read, the people are safer. I mean, all of that is partly because of American ingenuity and our abilities to not believe the naysayers that people is here and you're not going to find any more of this

BARTIROMO: So, is there -- is there a way to characterize the amount of supply that will be coming from the U.S.?

PERRY: Well, you know, I hesitate to be a forecaster of what the home markets are going to be. I'll leave that up to people that are substantially more into that.

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on. You're the Energy Secretary. Let me ask --

PERRY: My job is to make sure that it's -- the abundant supply and I want to get people together so that they know that America is going to be a reliant supplier of that energy. The price will work itself though.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised where prices are by the way because it feels like the markets are focused more on the potential for terrorism or disruption. Where oil is right now.

PERRY: Well, those are realities of the world. But the fact is that we have an amazing I mean, you think about Anwar that the Congress just opened up again. You know, the previous administration closed it down, Congress working with the administration said, you know what, those nine million barrels are really important to the United States and to the world. So opening up markets that the previous administration have closed. I think it's in a very powerful message around the world that we're going to be a reliant supplier of energy into the foreseeable future.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. And I think that's why there's change happening in Saudi Arabia.

PERRY: Indeed.

BARTIROMO: There is incredible change happening in other countries because they see what to expect from the U.S. By the way, what was behind the decision not to drill off of the coast of Florida?

PERRY: You know, I think that the administration through the Department of Interior sensitive to the issues there. There is plenty of space out there whether it's in the gulf, whether it's in Anwar, whether it's other areas that we can develop the energy resource we have. You know, the people of Florida said, hey listen, we don't want to add any new drilling platforms, the administration respected that.

BARTIROMO: And that was OK with the (INAUDIBLE) let me ask you about the President's news this week and that is these tariffs on solar panels and on washing machines, there is some conversation happening and as you know about worries about potential trade wars, about what China will do in response. Should we worry about a different trade stance from this administration?

PERRY: They shouldn't be worrying about this administration from the standpoint of transparency and fairness. That's what Donald Trump is all about. You want to compete against the United States, bring it but don't subsidize in a way that it's unfair, don't get into the market and try to gobble up all the market and then all of a sudden after you choked everybody else out of market, guess what, prices go up. This is a president that says, look, I get it about competition. But you're going to compete fairly, and you're going to compete on a level-playing field.

BARTIROMO: And the President said that as it relates to jobs as well and when you look at the energy story, that's a real job creator. Can you characterize what we might see from all of the drilling and the fracturing that will happen in terms of job creation?

PERRY: Well, it's going to continue on. I mean, that's obviously for the states that --

BARTIROMO: And consistent.

PERRY: And it's not just the jobs right in those states where it's happening, it's upstream or excuse me, it's downstream from that. It's the manufacturing. We think there is an incredible potential in the Appalachian region to turn that area into an absolute job-creating giant with the development of the Marcell or Shell with the other fossil fuels that are available there. You can duplicate the footprint of what you see along in Texas Gulf Coast in that Appalachian region and the jobs that get created. I'm promising you the governor of West Virginia and Ohio and Kentucky and Pennsylvania, they're going to be staying and they're saluting and saying, Mr. President, let's go, let's go make this happen, let's go make America great again.

BARTIROMO: And they're -- and these are high-paying jobs.

PERRY: Indeed. They are.

BARTIROMO: How do you like the job? How do you like the role of energy secretary? What's new that you can tell us with this?

PERRY: Most interesting job I've ever had. Best job ever had was governor of Texas but this one is the most interesting and the coolest job mostly because of the 17 national labs that are out there involved in everything from cybersecurity to the next wave of small-moderate reactors to, you know, just the most fascinating new things that are going to be on the horizon for America. Our national labs are involved in.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, thank you for your leadership.

PERRY: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Secretary Rick Perry. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. General Electric reported earnings that were below expectations, this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching the stock trade up -- Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good morning, Maria. We know that General Electric has been in a turnaround phase. In the last August, Flannery came on as the new CEO to turn this thing around. Today, look at that, just in the last half hour, you -- a short time ago, we're saying it was up 2-1/2 percent. And look now, it's up 5.2 percent. So, what happened here? We did see ultimately, that the company in the latest quarter, they're really focusing on the overall -- the restructuring plan. The weakness that they've seen in operating profit and the revenue but ultimately that they're focusing on the aviation and health care divisions where they are seeing some strength.

There has been talk about this company being beaten down, and don't forget, it's down about 45 percent in the last 12 months. Is now the time to finally get into General Electric? I know you've had this conversation with many of your guests, but there's been talk of dividing up the company in some way. But that the turnaround and restructuring is underway, but you are seeing the stock now getting a big jump, Maria. Now, it's up 5-1/2 percent at 17.78. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Nicole. From Disney to Verizon and Starbucks, more U.S. companies handing out bonus checks, hiking wages for their workers after the tax reform overhaul. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in on that. Stu, it's just incredible the number of companies.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, it's a flood. Look, I would call it a flood. Look, in the last 24 hours, we've got Disney, a thousand bucks to 125,000 employees, Verizon, I think is 2,500 bucks worth of stock to the employees; J.P. Morgan 10 percent wage increases for a big swath of their people. I mean, it's a long list, just in last 24 hours. It's clear, I think American business was on trial, they got everything they wanted from the tax cut deal, and now, they are indeed passing it along to the -- to the customers and also to their employees. But, you know, the big pass-through, I think, is still to come. I think that will come from the big tech companies of this world, when they repatriate all of that money. I think a lot of it goes to shareholders. And looking for stock buybacks like Comcast, for example, and I'm looking also for a dividend increases. That's the next round in this flood of pass-throughs and givebacks. Here it comes.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point. I would also add on to financial services, Stu, because, you know, the banks really haven't even had the actual impact of regulation rollback. You know, that's to come, so there's this enormous runway there as well.

VARNEY: Yes, look, it's a flood, that's what I'm saying. By the way, how is Davos treating you? Are being nice to you?

BARTIROMO: It's good. I mean, you know, everyone's talking about President Trump.

VARNEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Coming tomorrow, and wondering what he's going to say, so he's definitely making a splash even before he arrives, Stu.

VARNEY: Stick it to them, Mr. President

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in 10 min, Stu.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, right after "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tax reform trickle down, Verizon, Disney, Starbucks have all announced perks for their employees as a result of the new tax cuts. Joining me right now live from the World Economic Forum is the CEO of Campbell Soup, Denise Morrison. Denise, great to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

DENISE MORRISON, CEO, CAMPBELL SOUP: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the tax package?

MORRISON: Well, I think the tax reform will be beneficial for business. We at Campbell's are going to realize a benefit from the reduced rate being largely United States company, we bear a rate over 30 percent and we expected that will come down pretty significantly. And what we're going to do with that is invest in our brands and pay down debt because we just made a very large acquisition.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that acquisition. How does this acquisition fill in the whole that you were looking to do? What -- how does it give you a scale and tell us about the growth that you're expecting as a result?

MORRISON. Yes. Well, we've been on a journey to transform Campbell's and to transition our portfolio. Soup is a very important category but we now recognize that in order to deliver on the needs and wants of the next generation of consumers, we wanted to diversify our portfolio in the faster-growing spaces, and those spaces are health and well-being and snacking. And so, acquisitions were the key accelerator for that strategy.

BARTIROMO: And Lance, $50 a share in cash. A lot of people talked about this as really helping Snyder's-Lance -- helping the company fill in areas because people are looking for healthier options, wellness. Tell us about it.

MORRISON: We believe that this provides a snacking platform, a diversified snacking platform because we already have Pepperidge Farm, Arnott's, and Kelsen, so this adds more to the savory snacks in addition to the sweet snacks. And then if you start to think about our simple meals as convenient mini meals, it's right on trend with what the consumer is doing because, Maria, only 34 percent of consumers eat three square meals a day. Over 90 percent are snacking five times a day, so this is right on trend.

BARTIROMO: Interesting. So, the soup category, is that slowing down? I know the last quarter, a lot of people were worried that it showed that we're seeing a bit of a slowdown.

MORRISON: Yes, there are pockets of growth in the soup category, for example, we introduced a new Well Yes! Product that we co-created with consumers, and that's targeted for the younger generation, all clean label soups, so you can read every ingredient on the label, ingredients like quinoa and kale, right on trend. We also just closed on the acquisition of Pacific Foods, which is a soup and broth and plant-based beverage company. We're very excited about that company, and the growth rate of that brand is really exciting. So, we are starting to move into new spaces even within the soup category.

BARTIROMO: You've got to change as consumer tastes change and people are looking for healthier options like the kale and quinoa.

MORRISON: It always starts with the consumer. And if you keep your eye on the consumer, they will take you where you need to go. And we spend lots of times with the consumers, we shop with them, we cook with them, we eat with them. Our team is having so much fun, sometimes it's hard to get them to come back to work.

BARTIROMO: So, growth comes from acquisitions or organic?

MORRISON: Growth comes from both. You need to be innovation -- you have to have organic innovation and really push the thinking, you have to do some acquisitions but you also have to --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Thanks for joining us, everybody, we'l1 see you tomorrow. Here's Stuart and "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

VARNEY: Thanks very much, Maria. All right.

END

urn:contentItem:5WFD-9FB1-DY0W-42PJ-00000-00Trump Goes To Davos World Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have A2018-01-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:44ZLexisNexisTrump Goes To Davos World Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have ALanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Wednesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. It is Wednesday, January 24th. The top stories right now 8:00 A.M. on the East Coast. America First on the world stage. President Trump and his administration heads to Davos to tout the U.S. economy and lure big-name investors to America. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin making headline down the ground in Davos already. The dollar is down this morning after Secretary Mnuchin said a weaker dollar is good for the U.S. economy. He's not the only cabinet member making headlines. Earlier this morning, I spoke with Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen about the delegation to the World Economic Forum.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY: I think what this message is going to be is America First is not America alone. We need to partner, you know, as I said earlier, not one of us has the ability to do this alone. So we need to partner with the private secretary. We need to partner with our allies. We've seen those discussions with North Korea. We've seen that in Syria. We've seen that in Iran. We have to build coalitions to be able to attack these threats together and I think -- I think that's what you'll hear a lot about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The president's trip to Davos comes amid another case of trickle-down tax reform. Starbucks, the latest company passing on savings from the new tax law to its employees. The announcement coming on the heels of similar news from Disney, J.P. Morgan Chase, and Verizon and that was just yesterday. What the coffee giant is brewing up for its records coming up. New and more records from markets, the NASDAQ yesterday surged 52 points after Netflix stock jumped 10 percent. The S&P 500 also added all-time high this morning after another gain yesterday of 6 points quarter of a percent higher. The Dow pulled back yesterday but this morning we look at momentum on the upside we're expecting a pretty strong opening for the broader averages. Take a look at Futures with the Dow Industrials now at the highs of the morning. We're expecting a gain of 80 points right out of the gate a third of a percent higher, S&P 500 also higher by a quarter of a percent, and the NASDAQ adding on to yesterday's record performance.

In Europe, this morning different story. Take a look at the European indices lower across the board worst performer in the U.K. FT-100 down one half of one percent. In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher with the exception of Japan as you see the Nikkei averaging Japan down three- quarters of a percent overnight. Earnings, the story on Wall Street once again General Electric, Ford Motor, Comcast, all among the big names reporting their fourth quarter numbers. Comcast delivered a double beat earnings and revenue above estimates. General Electric missed estimates but look at the stock, it's up one and one and a half percent. Clearly, investors are seeing some value in G.E. shares after a 40 percent sell-off despite that miss on earnings.

Trouble patching the patch, well, Intel is still struggling to repair the glaring flaw in its chips sparking new concerns this morning for cybersecurity. Plus, hackers cash in on the cryptocurrency craze. The stunning amount stolen from the billions raised in initial coin offerings amid the Bitcoin boom. We will tell you about that. Also coming up this morning, joining the conversation Energy Secretary Rick Perry is with us this morning along with Dow CEO Andrew Liveris, the CEO of Cisco Chuck Robbins is here, and the CEO of Campbell Soup Denise Morrison.

Plus, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney weighs in. You don't want to miss the moments with them. We got a big hour coming up. First, this top story this hour, America First on the world stage. President Trump headed to the World Economic Forum in Davos. Tonight, he's expected to arrive tomorrow. Treasure Secretary Steven Mnuchin already on the ground here in Switzerland and he's making news. He had comments this morning saying that he welcomes a weakening dollar because it is good for trade. That sent the dollar to fresh new lows this morning. Though Mnuchin also emphasized America is open for business.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: We have a great story to tell, lots of important meetings. It's truly all about economic growth opportunities to invest free and fair trade, and kind of -- so we're looking forward to it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You can do that. If you don't want to, you don't have to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That's fine. This is coming as companies here in U.S. are giving back to their employees in the wake of the tax reform overhaul. President Trump just tweeted this, this morning. He says, tremendous investment by companies from all over the world being made in America. There has never been anything like it. The president writes now, Disney, JPMorgan Chase, and many others, massive regulation reduction tax cuts making the U.S. a powerhouse once again. He says, long way to go, jobs, jobs, jobs. Joining me now to weigh in is the Chairman and CEO of E.Y., Global Chairman and CEO Mark Weinberger. Mark, it's great to see you.

MARK WEINBERGER, GLOBAL CHAIRMAN AND CEO OF E.Y.: Always a pleasure, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So I know that you have been on panels this morning. You're talking to a lot of your customers and clients about what's taking place in the U.S. and the tax reform bill that is having a really big impact.

WEINBERGER: It is, Maria. We're seeing, you know, obviously, it doesn't make the U.S. a tax heaven but what it does do is give us a competitor rate and it allows companies to move their capital around without having to pay that extra level of tax. We are seeing supply changed being reevaluated, operations and investment being expanded and as you said, we're seeing a whole bunch of things like increasing wages, bonuses, pension payments, healthcare payments. The real question is you know it has been are the businesses going to give back to shareholders and stock buybacks and dividends or investing in capital and labor? I think you're going to see all of that but it's a positive -- definitely a positive momentum here in Davos.

BARTIROMO: And all of the above is positive?

WEINBERGER: All of the above are positive, gives back in the economy.

BARTIROMO: But let me ask you this because we see this tax plan having an immediate effect with the companies announcing these things, but this is really going to have a longer-term effect, isn't it?

WEINBERGER: That is a great point because everyone is saying, what's this going to do next quarter? This is a landmark tax reform bill that structurally changes business taxes like we haven't even done since 1960s. We talk about the 1986 Act. That was a lot of individual changes. International rules are written in the 60s. This completely changes how a company thinks about where to put his capital. It's not just U.S. businesses. We're talking to many Asian companies, European companies, who are looking to invest in the U.S. to get advantage of the full expensing, the lower corporate rate, and a number of other benefits of just being a great market.

BARTIROMO: And the President said that as it relates to jobs as well and when you look at the energy story, that's a real job creator. Can you characterize what we might see from all of the drilling and the fracturing that will happen in terms of job creation?

PERRY: Well, it's going to continue on. I mean, that's obviously for the states that --

BARTIROMO: And consistent.

PERRY: And it's not just the jobs right in those states where it's happening, it's upstream or excuse me, it's downstream from that. It's the manufacturing. We think there is an incredible potential in the Appalachian region to turn that area into an absolute job-creating giant with the development of the Marcell or Shell with the other fossil fuels that are available there. You can duplicate the footprint of what you see along in Texas Gulf Coast in that Appalachian region and the jobs that get created. I'm promising you the governor of West Virginia and Ohio and Kentucky and Pennsylvania, they're going to be staying and they're saluting and saying, Mr. President, let's go, let's go make this happen, let's go make America great again.

BARTIROMO: And they're -- and these are high-paying jobs.

PERRY: Indeed. They are.

BARTIROMO: How do you like the job? How do you like the role of energy secretary? What's new that you can tell us with this?

PERRY: Most interesting job I've ever had. Best job ever had was governor of Texas but this one is the most interesting and the coolest job mostly because of the 17 national labs that are out there involved in everything from cybersecurity to the next wave of small-moderate reactors to, you know, just the most fascinating new things that are going to be on the horizon for America. Our national labs are involved in.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, thank you for your leadership.

PERRY: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Secretary Rick Perry. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. General Electric reported earnings that were below expectations, this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching the stock trade up -- Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good morning, Maria. We know that General Electric has been in a turnaround phase. In the last August, Flannery came on as the new CEO to turn this thing around. Today, look at that, just in the last half hour, you -- a short time ago, we're saying it was up 2-1/2 percent. And look now, it's up 5.2 percent. So, what happened here? We did see ultimately, that the company in the latest quarter, they're really focusing on the overall -- the restructuring plan. The weakness that they've seen in operating profit and the revenue but ultimately that they're focusing on the aviation and health care divisions where they are seeing some strength.

There has been talk about this company being beaten down, and don't forget, it's down about 45 percent in the last 12 months. Is now the time to finally get into General Electric? I know you've had this conversation with many of your guests, but there's been talk of dividing up the company in some way. But that the turnaround and restructuring is underway, but you are seeing the stock now getting a big jump, Maria. Now, it's up 5-1/2 percent at 17.78. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Nicole. From Disney to Verizon and Starbucks, more U.S. companies handing out bonus checks, hiking wages for their workers after the tax reform overhaul. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in on that. Stu, it's just incredible the number of companies.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, it's a flood. Look, I would call it a flood. Look, in the last 24 hours, we've got Disney, a thousand bucks to 125,000 employees, Verizon, I think is 2,500 bucks worth of stock to the employees; J.P. Morgan 10 percent wage increases for a big swath of their people. I mean, it's a long list, just in last 24 hours. It's clear, I think American business was on trial, they got everything they wanted from the tax cut deal, and now, they are indeed passing it along to the -- to the customers and also to their employees. But, you know, the big pass-through, I think, is still to come. I think that will come from the big tech companies of this world, when they repatriate all of that money. I think a lot of it goes to shareholders. And looking for stock buybacks like Comcast, for example, and I'm looking also for a dividend increases. That's the next round in this flood of pass-throughs and givebacks. Here it comes.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point. I would also add on to financial services, Stu, because, you know, the banks really haven't even had the actual impact of regulation rollback. You know, that's to come, so there's this enormous runway there as well.

VARNEY: Yes, look, it's a flood, that's what I'm saying. By the way, how is Davos treating you? Are being nice to you?

BARTIROMO: It's good. I mean, you know, everyone's talking about President Trump.

VARNEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Coming tomorrow, and wondering what he's going to say, so he's definitely making a splash even before he arrives, Stu.

VARNEY: Stick it to them, Mr. President

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in 10 min, Stu.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, right after "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tax reform trickle down, Verizon, Disney, Starbucks have all announced perks for their employees as a result of the new tax cuts. Joining me right now live from the World Economic Forum is the CEO of Campbell Soup, Denise Morrison. Denise, great to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

DENISE MORRISON, CEO, CAMPBELL SOUP: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the tax package?

MORRISON: Well, I think the tax reform will be beneficial for business. We at Campbell's are going to realize a benefit from the reduced rate being largely United States company, we bear a rate over 30 percent and we expected that will come down pretty significantly. And what we're going to do with that is invest in our brands and pay down debt because we just made a very large acquisition.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that acquisition. How does this acquisition fill in the whole that you were looking to do? What -- how does it give you a scale and tell us about the growth that you're expecting as a result?

MORRISON. Yes. Well, we've been on a journey to transform Campbell's and to transition our portfolio. Soup is a very important category but we now recognize that in order to deliver on the needs and wants of the next generation of consumers, we wanted to diversify our portfolio in the faster-growing spaces, and those spaces are health and well-being and snacking. And so, acquisitions were the key accelerator for that strategy.

BARTIROMO: And Lance, $50 a share in cash. A lot of people talked about this as really helping Snyder's-Lance -- helping the company fill in areas because people are looking for healthier options, wellness. Tell us about it.

MORRISON: We believe that this provides a snacking platform, a diversified snacking platform because we already have Pepperidge Farm, Arnott's, and Kelsen, so this adds more to the savory snacks in addition to the sweet snacks. And then if you start to think about our simple meals as convenient mini meals, it's right on trend with what the consumer is doing because, Maria, only 34 percent of consumers eat three square meals a day. Over 90 percent are snacking five times a day, so this is right on trend.

BARTIROMO: Interesting. So, the soup category, is that slowing down? I know the last quarter, a lot of people were worried that it showed that we're seeing a bit of a slowdown.

MORRISON: Yes, there are pockets of growth in the soup category, for example, we introduced a new Well Yes! Product that we co-created with consumers, and that's targeted for the younger generation, all clean label soups, so you can read every ingredient on the label, ingredients like quinoa and kale, right on trend. We also just closed on the acquisition of Pacific Foods, which is a soup and broth and plant-based beverage company. We're very excited about that company, and the growth rate of that brand is really exciting. So, we are starting to move into new spaces even within the soup category.

BARTIROMO: You've got to change as consumer tastes change and people are looking for healthier options like the kale and quinoa.

MORRISON: It always starts with the consumer. And if you keep your eye on the consumer, they will take you where you need to go. And we spend lots of times with the consumers, we shop with them, we cook with them, we eat with them. Our team is having so much fun, sometimes it's hard to get them to come back to work.

BARTIROMO: So, growth comes from acquisitions or organic?

MORRISON: Growth comes from both. You need to be innovation -- you have to have organic innovation and really push the thinking, you have to do some acquisitions but you also have to --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Thanks for joining us, everybody, we'l1 see you tomorrow. Here's Stuart and "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

VARNEY: Thanks very much, Maria. All right.

END

urn:contentItem:5RGJ-Y8F1-DXH2-6359-00000-00Trump Goes To Davos World Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have A Major Design Flaw And The Fix Means Slower PCs2018-01-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMark Weinberger; Andrew Liveris; Chuck Robbins, Rick Perry, Denise MorrisonNEWSFinancial012403cb.231Trump Goes To DavosWorld Economic Forum With Cabinet Group; Europe Takes Center Stage In Davos Ahead Of Trump Arrival; Intel Chips Have A Major Design Flaw And The Fix Means Slower PCsMaria Bartiromo, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Wednesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. It is Wednesday, January 24th. The top stories right now 8:00 A.M. on the East Coast. America First on the world stage. President Trump and his administration heads to Davos to tout the U.S. economy and lure big-name investors to America. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin making headline down the ground in Davos already. The dollar is down this morning after Secretary Mnuchin said a weaker dollar is good for the U.S. economy. He's not the only cabinet member making headlines. Earlier this morning, I spoke with Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen about the delegation to the World Economic Forum.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY: I think what this message is going to be is America First is not America alone. We need to partner, you know, as I said earlier, not one of us has the ability to do this alone. So we need to partner with the private secretary. We need to partner with our allies. We've seen those discussions with North Korea. We've seen that in Syria. We've seen that in Iran. We have to build coalitions to be able to attack these threats together and I think -- I think that's what you'll hear a lot about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The president's trip to Davos comes amid another case of trickle-down tax reform. Starbucks, the latest company passing on savings from the new tax law to its employees. The announcement coming on the heels of similar news from Disney, J.P. Morgan Chase, and Verizon and that was just yesterday. What the coffee giant is brewing up for its records coming up. New and more records from markets, the NASDAQ yesterday surged 52 points after Netflix stock jumped 10 percent. The S&P 500 also added all-time high this morning after another gain yesterday of 6 points quarter of a percent higher. The Dow pulled back yesterday but this morning we look at momentum on the upside we're expecting a pretty strong opening for the broader averages. Take a look at Futures with the Dow Industrials now at the highs of the morning. We're expecting a gain of 80 points right out of the gate a third of a percent higher, S&P 500 also higher by a quarter of a percent, and the NASDAQ adding on to yesterday's record performance.

In Europe, this morning different story. Take a look at the European indices lower across the board worst performer in the U.K. FT-100 down one half of one percent. In Asia overnight, markets closed mostly higher with the exception of Japan as you see the Nikkei averaging Japan down three- quarters of a percent overnight. Earnings, the story on Wall Street once again General Electric, Ford Motor, Comcast, all among the big names reporting their fourth quarter numbers. Comcast delivered a double beat earnings and revenue above estimates. General Electric missed estimates but look at the stock, it's up one and one and a half percent. Clearly, investors are seeing some value in G.E. shares after a 40 percent sell-off despite that miss on earnings.

Trouble patching the patch, well, Intel is still struggling to repair the glaring flaw in its chips sparking new concerns this morning for cybersecurity. Plus, hackers cash in on the cryptocurrency craze. The stunning amount stolen from the billions raised in initial coin offerings amid the Bitcoin boom. We will tell you about that. Also coming up this morning, joining the conversation Energy Secretary Rick Perry is with us this morning along with Dow CEO Andrew Liveris, the CEO of Cisco Chuck Robbins is here, and the CEO of Campbell Soup Denise Morrison.

Plus, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney weighs in. You don't want to miss the moments with them. We got a big hour coming up. First, this top story this hour, America First on the world stage. President Trump headed to the World Economic Forum in Davos. Tonight, he's expected to arrive tomorrow. Treasure Secretary Steven Mnuchin already on the ground here in Switzerland and he's making news. He had comments this morning saying that he welcomes a weakening dollar because it is good for trade. That sent the dollar to fresh new lows this morning. Though Mnuchin also emphasized America is open for business.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: We have a great story to tell, lots of important meetings. It's truly all about economic growth opportunities to invest free and fair trade, and kind of -- so we're looking forward to it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You can do that. If you don't want to, you don't have to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That's fine. This is coming as companies here in U.S. are giving back to their employees in the wake of the tax reform overhaul. President Trump just tweeted this, this morning. He says, tremendous investment by companies from all over the world being made in America. There has never been anything like it. The president writes now, Disney, JPMorgan Chase, and many others, massive regulation reduction tax cuts making the U.S. a powerhouse once again. He says, long way to go, jobs, jobs, jobs. Joining me now to weigh in is the Chairman and CEO of E.Y., Global Chairman and CEO Mark Weinberger. Mark, it's great to see you.

MARK WEINBERGER, GLOBAL CHAIRMAN AND CEO OF E.Y.: Always a pleasure, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So I know that you have been on panels this morning. You're talking to a lot of your customers and clients about what's taking place in the U.S. and the tax reform bill that is having a really big impact.

WEINBERGER: It is, Maria. We're seeing, you know, obviously, it doesn't make the U.S. a tax heaven but what it does do is give us a competitor rate and it allows companies to move their capital around without having to pay that extra level of tax. We are seeing supply changed being reevaluated, operations and investment being expanded and as you said, we're seeing a whole bunch of things like increasing wages, bonuses, pension payments, healthcare payments. The real question is you know it has been are the businesses going to give back to shareholders and stock buybacks and dividends or investing in capital and labor? I think you're going to see all of that but it's a positive -- definitely a positive momentum here in Davos.

BARTIROMO: And all of the above is positive?

WEINBERGER: All of the above are positive, gives back in the economy.

BARTIROMO: But let me ask you this because we see this tax plan having an immediate effect with the companies announcing these things, but this is really going to have a longer-term effect, isn't it?

WEINBERGER: That is a great point because everyone is saying, what's this going to do next quarter? This is a landmark tax reform bill that structurally changes business taxes like we haven't even done since 1960s. We talk about the 1986 Act. That was a lot of individual changes. International rules are written in the 60s. This completely changes how a company thinks about where to put his capital. It's not just U.S. businesses. We're talking to many Asian companies, European companies, who are looking to invest in the U.S. to get advantage of the full expensing, the lower corporate rate, and a number of other benefits of just being a great market.

BARTIROMO: That's right. I was speaking to a European player recently and he said, we had a whole plan to invest in Europe. We've shifted that plan and now we'll be investing in America which is --

WEINBERGER: We'll see more of that.

BARTIROMO: Which is very positive. All right. There's that. The president and his administration getting high marks on the tax reform package. No doubt about it. But then there's trade where there are some questions. The president yesterday announced steep tariffs on solar panels, on washing machines while 11 Pacific Rim countries agreed to forge a new commercial block that excludes the U.S., obviously, the U.S. pulling out of the TPP, what's your take on what's happening with regards to trade?

WEINBERGER: So I think the speech is you and your league, you talked about it's going to be really important because the president has to balance and enforcing the laws. I mean this, you know, putting tariffs on solar isn't, you know, changing the whole landscape of trade, in fact, from 2012 and 2015, we had tariffs on solar. So there are really uncertainty now is where is he go next? And we need to be involved in trade deals around the world. We can't be left out. Ninety-five percent of the world's consumers, 80 percent of GDP growth is outside the United States. So businesses want to be able to go there. The U.S. is and open market. We let everybody in. Trade deals are good for businesses. In the U.S., they create jobs. So the question is going to be, does this lead to more and more retaliation and trade wars? Or is this enforcement of existing deals and renegotiations of NAFTA or renegotiations of course, and discussions with China to get to a positive trade deal? That's what everyone is going to be watching.

BARTIROMO: So one of the issues with NAFTA is it basically sets the companies, look, you can have a factory overseas in Mexico and you can produce cheap stuff and then you can send them back to the U.S. and sell them in U.S., so of course, companies are going to do just that in higher workers at a much lower wage in Mexico. And then once NAFTA was completed and then everybody started doing that, that became the template for all trade deals?

WEINBERGER: Well, it's true. But if you think -- but there are so many examples where you know, well, I mean how do you even implement as you don't know what the cargo -- component parts going over and back across the border in Canada six times.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

WEINBERGER: And iPhone is 800 different companies worked on an iPhone in 31 different countries and the component parts all come together into the United States, so --

BARTIROMO: So what are they going to do, pay a tariff every time they cross --

WEINBERGER: They couldn't do it. You couldn't afford an iPhone if you had a tariff every level of the company in the United States. You couldn't get the labor done if you try to bring it all back to the United States. So we need to understand that this helps the United States too to have these trade deals in place.

BARTIROMO: So there's got to a balance between fair trade but also not hurting the customer because ultimately that's going to fall on the consumer who's going to pay more for a product because the company that makes it is paying a tariff?

WEINBERGER: Absolutely. It's like a tax here that we just reduced. So but you're in the nail in the head, Maria, as always. The pivot we got to watch and see right now from feeding up on our trading partners. First, a lot of bad deals and upgrading necessarily trade deals to starting to negotiating positively the new deals. Seeing if NAFTA will get done this year. We have a lot of negotiations coming up this month, of course, the Mexican elections coming up on midterms and coming up makes it hard. Mercosur is positively moving forward, so we're going to try and negotiate that. We got to make progress in those deals and that will set a good signal.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me ask you, Mark. And turn to -- turn to Bitcoin because according to new research, you and Ernst & Young did recently more than 10 percent of funds raised through initial coin offerings are lost or stolen in hacker attacks?

WEINBERGER: Yes. Well, this is -- as we know, it's a really complicated area and, you know, these coin offerings are plenty. There's over a hundred different indexes out there where they're coming in there's offerings. They are obviously susceptible to fraud and theft. They become more of an investment than a currency and so I think appropriately you have the government to look at it where we point it out there is that investors -- it's not an investor. It's really a tool to be a currency. You have to be cautious how you're investing in it.

BARTIROMO: One more risk to watch around Bitcoin?

WEINBERGER: Always, a lot more.

BARTIROMO: Mark, great to see you.

WEINBERGER: Always, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are live this week at the World Economic Forum here in Davos, Switzerland. President Trump will be here tomorrow. BARTIROMO: It's very important because we're seeing machine learning take over jobs and we're seeing new skillsets really required. OK. So positive marks on the tax reform package. We know that. And I think we all have to engage in that topic, so what are these rules? OK. It isn't just about putting tariffs on and on that tariff question, I mean we Dow make a polysilicon. That's a -- the raw material for solar panels. We've been excluded from the China market for the last five years, so that's not far. So these tariffs on solar panels is a way of sending a signal that it can't be one way. It can't be one-way trade and I support the president on that.

BARTIROMO: This is really important because you've actually seen firsthand the impact of much cheaper products coming from China.

LIVERIS: Absolutely. And then, so American workers, we can't -- we are now having plants at risks, factories at risks because I can't access the China market and they favor their own producers, yet the solar panels are being -- coming over here and killing our solar panel industry in the United States. So there needs to be a recalibration with lots of conversation with Secretary Ross in the USTR on this topic. So that's an example of recalibrating the rules of trade and I'm all for that, but I think we need to get the facts on the table, get the rhetoric out of room, and, you know, what are these rules of engagement in terms of fair trade.

BARTIROMO: This is the first explanation that really I've heard that make so much sense because you're right there and you're feeling it firsthand. LIVERIS: Well, since antiquity and city-states, and bartering view, of course, get tit-for-tat. You, of course, get retaliation. This is what negotiation is. This president is a negotiator. BARTIROMO: Do you think we're going to see more of this like for example as it relates to aluminum and steel because the president did say -- he mentioned aluminum and steel and I think that is getting some people nervous that we're going to see more and more of this kind of tariff behavior and it's --

LIVERIS: Well, I'm not in -- I'm not in the room that decides which ones but I am telling you, if I look at chemicals, for example, we have a surplus. We're the second largest exporter from the United States. BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. And you've given us phenomenal insight into this. Andrew, thank you for that.

LIVERIS: Not at all.

BARTIROMO: You are such a retire as Chairman of DowDuPont later this year after overseeing its historic deal the merger late last year. Now, I know you are reporting earnings. We're on track. And look, I can't be happier about the way the cultures of being assimilating, the integration work. BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point.

LIVERIS: Good packaging, what we do with food packaging, what we do with plastics in the ocean, what we do with carbon emissions, these are all opportunities for these companies would it be the agricultural one or the materials one, or the specialty ones, water, and water reuse, waste management, waste reuse, these are the opportunities that we're addressing through using out 7500 scientists.

BARTIROMO: So this is where the growth comes from?

LIVERIS: That's where it comes from.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about regulation. Obviously, this president has been rolling back regulations, have you felt it in your sector because I know other sectors they're not there yet and it sort of the smaller runway, what have you seen?

LIVERIS: Look, I can't speak strongly enough about how much we've felt it. It's not just -- it's not just the attitude. It's being specific and we've been asked, and it's kind of nice to be consulted to be at the front end of this, to use science, to say this regulation makes sense. This one doesn't. This administration has been unafraid to roll back regulations that make no sense. We felt it. We're feeling it on our bottom line. But more importantly, we're seeing it in a change in attitude on what's the smarter regulation. We are for regulation. We just want the right type of regulation to actually manage the behaviors of everyone in the value chain. We're a big player.

BARTIROMO: And the pendulum just swung way too far. Andrew, it's great to see you.

LIVERIS: Always going to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Andrew Liveris there. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

So here we're having conversations about how do we redefine the architecture inside a vehicle. Those are the conversations we're having now. ROBBINS: Well, if you look at -- it's happening across every industry today. Primarily, we have seen early adoption in manufacturing of this industrial internet. We've seen retail move.

ROBBINS: That's great.

ROBBINS: The matter of the issue is as we connect vehicles, as we connect vending machines, manufacturing facilities whatever they are, Cisco is the largest machine, the machine connectivity platform. BARTIROMO: Wonderful. Chuck, I'm so sorry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Here again Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA live from Davos, Switzerland at the World Economic Forum.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, January 24th. Your top stories right now 8:34 on the East Coast. RICK PERRY, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF ENERGY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. The President's America First message, how do you think it will be received?

PERRY: Well, I think he have to understand what America First means to the President and the administration. It's really pretty simple from my perspective. This is about America being competitive around the globe. When folks were thinking about where you want to buy your energy from, where do you want that next load of LNG to come from? We want you to think about America first.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a good way to put it. Well, the President has stressed really tapping into our oil reserves in America. Let's talk about that and where the opportunities are from your standpoint.

PERRY: Yes. Well, you think about 10 plus years ago and then 2005 we were -- besides ourselves, if you will and behind, other places where the oil and gas was coming from, you know, we had founded all, Peak oil. We heard all of those stories and then, you know, by the grace of God and some technology and a god by named George Mitchell from Texas, hydraulic fracturing came into play in a really big way and we were able to go into those tight shell formations and develop that which is now creating an absolute revolution in the oil and gas industry and completely changing the geopolitical dynamics in the world with America being at the forefront. We are now the number one oil and gas producing nation on the face of the earth. I mean, who would have thought that a decade ago that that would have been true. But it puts us in a very unique place. And here is what I try to share with all of our allies and for all the audience here at Davos is that the United States is not just exporting energy, we're exporting freedom. We're exporting to our allies in Europe. The opportunity to truly have a choice of where do you buy your energy from. That's freedom, and that kind of freedom is priceless.

BARTIROMO: This is a really important point that you're making because for a long time America was reliant on places like Saudi Arabia and Russia to get energy but today it's a completely different situation in America. How significant is it? I mean, how would you characterize the supply that will be coming from the U.S. or to the global markets.

PERRY: You know, I'm not sure anything since World War II has been anymore dynamic from my perspective than they shift in the energy supply, energy control if you will. And again, the United States in the back controlling a country with this industry. It's about literally freeing up our allies around the world. Letting them know that we're going to be there for them, there's no strings attached when you buy American LNG. So, that is -- that's world-changing. And truly, this president, that's his message here. Is that the United States is -- it's a new day. The fossil fuels that we're going to be relying them on for decades to come are going to be available. Now, is our technology going to be able to allow us to use it wiser? With better results for the environment? Absolutely. The CCCU, the carbon capture utilization, we're doing projects with Saudi Arabia.

I'll see my counterpart (INAUDIBLE) today on a panel, we'll talk about the projects that we're working on together. The UAE, Qatar, all of those countries as we come together to develop and supply the rest of the world with the power so that they can have manufacturing (INAUDIBLE) in Africa. Being able to, you know, literally turn the lights on when the sun goes down so that their children can read, the people are safer. I mean, all of that is partly because of American ingenuity and our abilities to not believe the naysayers that people is here and you're not going to find any more of this

BARTIROMO: So, is there -- is there a way to characterize the amount of supply that will be coming from the U.S.?

PERRY: Well, you know, I hesitate to be a forecaster of what the home markets are going to be. I'll leave that up to people that are substantially more into that.

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on. You're the Energy Secretary. Let me ask --

PERRY: My job is to make sure that it's -- the abundant supply and I want to get people together so that they know that America is going to be a reliant supplier of that energy. The price will work itself though.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised where prices are by the way because it feels like the markets are focused more on the potential for terrorism or disruption. Where oil is right now.

PERRY: Well, those are realities of the world. But the fact is that we have an amazing I mean, you think about Anwar that the Congress just opened up again. You know, the previous administration closed it down, Congress working with the administration said, you know what, those nine million barrels are really important to the United States and to the world. So opening up markets that the previous administration have closed. I think it's in a very powerful message around the world that we're going to be a reliant supplier of energy into the foreseeable future.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. And I think that's why there's change happening in Saudi Arabia.

PERRY: Indeed.

BARTIROMO: There is incredible change happening in other countries because they see what to expect from the U.S. By the way, what was behind the decision not to drill off of the coast of Florida?

PERRY: You know, I think that the administration through the Department of Interior sensitive to the issues there. There is plenty of space out there whether it's in the gulf, whether it's in Anwar, whether it's other areas that we can develop the energy resource we have. You know, the people of Florida said, hey listen, we don't want to add any new drilling platforms, the administration respected that.

BARTIROMO: And that was OK with the (INAUDIBLE) let me ask you about the President's news this week and that is these tariffs on solar panels and on washing machines, there is some conversation happening and as you know about worries about potential trade wars, about what China will do in response. Should we worry about a different trade stance from this administration?

PERRY: They shouldn't be worrying about this administration from the standpoint of transparency and fairness. That's what Donald Trump is all about. You want to compete against the United States, bring it but don't subsidize in a way that it's unfair, don't get into the market and try to gobble up all the market and then all of a sudden after you choked everybody else out of market, guess what, prices go up. This is a president that says, look, I get it about competition. But you're going to compete fairly, and you're going to compete on a level-playing field.

BARTIROMO: And the President said that as it relates to jobs as well and when you look at the energy story, that's a real job creator. Can you characterize what we might see from all of the drilling and the fracturing that will happen in terms of job creation?

PERRY: Well, it's going to continue on. I mean, that's obviously for the states that --

BARTIROMO: And consistent.

PERRY: And it's not just the jobs right in those states where it's happening, it's upstream or excuse me, it's downstream from that. It's the manufacturing. We think there is an incredible potential in the Appalachian region to turn that area into an absolute job-creating giant with the development of the Marcell or Shell with the other fossil fuels that are available there. You can duplicate the footprint of what you see along in Texas Gulf Coast in that Appalachian region and the jobs that get created. I'm promising you the governor of West Virginia and Ohio and Kentucky and Pennsylvania, they're going to be staying and they're saluting and saying, Mr. President, let's go, let's go make this happen, let's go make America great again.

BARTIROMO: And they're -- and these are high-paying jobs.

PERRY: Indeed. They are.

BARTIROMO: How do you like the job? How do you like the role of energy secretary? What's new that you can tell us with this?

PERRY: Most interesting job I've ever had. Best job ever had was governor of Texas but this one is the most interesting and the coolest job mostly because of the 17 national labs that are out there involved in everything from cybersecurity to the next wave of small-moderate reactors to, you know, just the most fascinating new things that are going to be on the horizon for America. Our national labs are involved in.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, thank you for your leadership.

PERRY: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Secretary Rick Perry. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. General Electric reported earnings that were below expectations, this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching the stock trade up -- Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good morning, Maria. We know that General Electric has been in a turnaround phase. In the last August, Flannery came on as the new CEO to turn this thing around. Today, look at that, just in the last half hour, you -- a short time ago, we're saying it was up 2-1/2 percent. And look now, it's up 5.2 percent. So, what happened here? We did see ultimately, that the company in the latest quarter, they're really focusing on the overall -- the restructuring plan. The weakness that they've seen in operating profit and the revenue but ultimately that they're focusing on the aviation and health care divisions where they are seeing some strength.

There has been talk about this company being beaten down, and don't forget, it's down about 45 percent in the last 12 months. Is now the time to finally get into General Electric? I know you've had this conversation with many of your guests, but there's been talk of dividing up the company in some way. But that the turnaround and restructuring is underway, but you are seeing the stock now getting a big jump, Maria. Now, it's up 5-1/2 percent at 17.78. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Nicole. From Disney to Verizon and Starbucks, more U.S. companies handing out bonus checks, hiking wages for their workers after the tax reform overhaul. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in on that. Stu, it's just incredible the number of companies.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, it's a flood. Look, I would call it a flood. Look, in the last 24 hours, we've got Disney, a thousand bucks to 125,000 employees, Verizon, I think is 2,500 bucks worth of stock to the employees; J.P. Morgan 10 percent wage increases for a big swath of their people. I mean, it's a long list, just in last 24 hours. It's clear, I think American business was on trial, they got everything they wanted from the tax cut deal, and now, they are indeed passing it along to the -- to the customers and also to their employees. But, you know, the big pass-through, I think, is still to come. I think that will come from the big tech companies of this world, when they repatriate all of that money. I think a lot of it goes to shareholders. And looking for stock buybacks like Comcast, for example, and I'm looking also for a dividend increases. That's the next round in this flood of pass-throughs and givebacks. Here it comes.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point. I would also add on to financial services, Stu, because, you know, the banks really haven't even had the actual impact of regulation rollback. You know, that's to come, so there's this enormous runway there as well.

VARNEY: Yes, look, it's a flood, that's what I'm saying. By the way, how is Davos treating you? Are being nice to you?

BARTIROMO: It's good. I mean, you know, everyone's talking about President Trump.

VARNEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Coming tomorrow, and wondering what he's going to say, so he's definitely making a splash even before he arrives, Stu.

VARNEY: Stick it to them, Mr. President

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in 10 min, Stu.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, right after "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tax reform trickle down, Verizon, Disney, Starbucks have all announced perks for their employees as a result of the new tax cuts. Joining me right now live from the World Economic Forum is the CEO of Campbell Soup, Denise Morrison. Denise, great to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

DENISE MORRISON, CEO, CAMPBELL SOUP: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the tax package?

MORRISON: Well, I think the tax reform will be beneficial for business. We at Campbell's are going to realize a benefit from the reduced rate being largely United States company, we bear a rate over 30 percent and we expected that will come down pretty significantly. And what we're going to do with that is invest in our brands and pay down debt because we just made a very large acquisition.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that acquisition. How does this acquisition fill in the whole that you were looking to do? What -- how does it give you a scale and tell us about the growth that you're expecting as a result?

MORRISON. Yes. Well, we've been on a journey to transform Campbell's and to transition our portfolio. Soup is a very important category but we now recognize that in order to deliver on the needs and wants of the next generation of consumers, we wanted to diversify our portfolio in the faster-growing spaces, and those spaces are health and well-being and snacking. And so, acquisitions were the key accelerator for that strategy.

BARTIROMO: And Lance, $50 a share in cash. A lot of people talked about this as really helping Snyder's-Lance -- helping the company fill in areas because people are looking for healthier options, wellness. Tell us about it.

MORRISON: We believe that this provides a snacking platform, a diversified snacking platform because we already have Pepperidge Farm, Arnott's, and Kelsen, so this adds more to the savory snacks in addition to the sweet snacks. And then if you start to think about our simple meals as convenient mini meals, it's right on trend with what the consumer is doing because, Maria, only 34 percent of consumers eat three square meals a day. Over 90 percent are snacking five times a day, so this is right on trend.

BARTIROMO: Interesting. So, the soup category, is that slowing down? I know the last quarter, a lot of people were worried that it showed that we're seeing a bit of a slowdown.

MORRISON: Yes, there are pockets of growth in the soup category, for example, we introduced a new Well Yes! Product that we co-created with consumers, and that's targeted for the younger generation, all clean label soups, so you can read every ingredient on the label, ingredients like quinoa and kale, right on trend. We also just closed on the acquisition of Pacific Foods, which is a soup and broth and plant-based beverage company. We're very excited about that company, and the growth rate of that brand is really exciting. So, we are starting to move into new spaces even within the soup category.

BARTIROMO: You've got to change as consumer tastes change and people are looking for healthier options like the kale and quinoa.

MORRISON: It always starts with the consumer. And if you keep your eye on the consumer, they will take you where you need to go. And we spend lots of times with the consumers, we shop with them, we cook with them, we eat with them. Our team is having so much fun, sometimes it's hard to get them to come back to work.

BARTIROMO: So, growth comes from acquisitions or organic?

MORRISON: Growth comes from both. You need to be innovation -- you have to have organic innovation and really push the thinking, you have to do some acquisitions but you also have to --

BARTIROMO: Thanks for joining us, everybody, we'l1 see you tomorrow. Here's Stuart and "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

VARNEY: Thanks very much, Maria. All right.

urn:contentItem:5WMS-WWS1-DYT8-R1WP-00000-00Trump hails conservatives for bypassing fake news2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:44ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. P2ATrump hails conservatives for bypassing fake newsKevin Freking and Marcy Gordon The Associated Press

WASHINGTON - President Donald Trump told the conservative critics of social media Thursday that they've successfully used the platforms to send messages directly to the American people without going through the "fake news filter.

Trump has weaponized social media to eviscerate opponents and promote himself. He convened Thursday's White House "social media summit of like-minded critics of Big Tech, excluding representatives from the very platforms he exploits.

Earlier Thursday, Trump sent a stream of Twitter messages lashing out at social media companies and the press, familiar targets that resonate with his conservative base.

The meeting represented an escalation of Trump's battle with companies like Facebook, Google and even his preferred communications outlet, Twitter. The president has claimed, without evidence, that the companies are "against me and even suggested U.S. regulators should sue them on grounds of anti-conservative bias.

In remarks to the participants, whom Trump called "online journalists and influencers, Trump said, "You're challenging the media gatekeepers and corporate censors to bring the truth to the American people.

"You communicate directly with our citizens without going through the fake news filter, he said.

The high-profile White House event raised the prospect of Trump using the forum to signal tough actions ahead by his administration against big tech companies in the areas of competition and privacy.

The firms already are under closer scrutiny than ever by regulators and in Congress following a stream of scandals including Facebook's lapses opening the personal data of millions of users to Trump's 2016 campaign, and a bipartisan push for new data privacy legislation has emerged in Congress. Regulators at the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are pursuing antitrust investigations of Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon.

Trump's volley of Twitter messages Thursday had familiar targets - "certain companies, the press and his Democratic rivals - that have proven resonance with his political base. The president predicted, without foundation, the demise of the press and the social media platforms if he loses to a Democrat in 2020. He hailed himself as "so great looking and smart, a true Stable Genius!

A "big subject of the summit would be "the tremendous dishonesty, bias, discrimination and suppression practiced by certain companies, Trump said in his tweets.

"We will not let them get away with it much longer, he said.

Among the conservative organizations expected to participate in the White House meeting are Turning Point USA, a nonprofit; PragerU, short for Prager University, which puts out short videos with a conservative perspective on politics and economics; the Media Research Center; and the Heritage Foundation, a Washington think tank.

Accusations commonly leveled by conservatives against the social media platforms include anti-religious bias, a tilt against abortion foes and censorship of conservative political views.

Trump has made it a priority to reach out to voters who oppose abortion. The anti-abortion groups Live Action and Susan B. Anthony List say Twitter has blocked their advertising. By policy, Twitter prohibits paid ads with content "that is inflammatory or provocative and is likely to evoke a strong negative reaction.

Donald Trump Jr. weighed in on the subject Wednesday, tweeting, "Twitter: We won't allow pro-life groups like @LiveAction to run ads on our platform' & if you're a conservative we might ban you for 1st Amendment protected speech that we arbitrarily deem offensive.'

While some Silicon Valley company executives may lean liberal, they have asserted that their products are without political bias.

Representatives for Facebook, Google and Twitter have declined to comment specifically on the White House meeting. The Internet Association, the industry's major trade group representing Facebook, Google and dozens of other companies, said online platforms "are the best tool for promoting voices from all political perspectives in history.

"Internet companies are not biased against any political ideology, and conservative voices in particular have used social media to great effect, the group's president Michael Beckerman said in a statement Thursday. "Internet companies depend upon their users' trust from across the political spectrum to grow and succeed.

Facebook has banned extremist figures such as Alex Jones of Infowars and Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam. Twitter has banned hate speech on the basis of someone's race, gender and other categories. Twitter broadened its policy this week to include banning language that dehumanizes others based on religion, and the company said it may also ban similar language aimed at other groups, such as those defined by gender, race and sexual orientation.

"I've never seen evidence of tech firm bias against conservatives, said Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., who has been sharply critical of the big companies for reasons of their market dominance and effect on competition. He leads a House Judiciary subcommittee that has opened a bipartisan probe into the tech giants' market conduct.

"If someone wants to show me some empirical data, instead of some alt-right member's paranoid claims, I'd appreciate it, Cicilline said in a statement Wednesday.

Trump has an estimated 61 million followers on Twitter and uses the platform almost daily to speak directly to his followers. He has a knack for tweeting outrageous, divisive or tongue-in-cheek missives that spur frenzied reactions from the mainstream press.

At the same time, Trump has accused Twitter, without evidence, of making it "very hard for people to join me and "very much harder for me to get out the message.
